1.brief: an appellation, as amark or memorial of individuality; by implication honor, authority, character
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
Mitsrajim, i.e. Upper and Lower Egypt
properly, nearness (used only as a preposition or an adverb), near; hence, generally, with, by, at, among, etc.
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)

2.brief: Shimon, one of Jacob's sons, also the tribe descended from him
Jehudah (or Judah), the name of five Israelites; also of the tribe descended from the first, and of its territory

3.brief: Zebulon, a son of Jacob; also his territory and tribe
Binjamin, youngest son of Jacob; also the tribe descended from him, and its territory

4.brief: Dan, one of the sons of Jacob; also the tribe descended from him, and its territory; likewise a place in Palestine colonized by them
Naphtali, a son of Jacob, with the tribe descended from him, and its territory
Gad, a son of Jacob, including his tribe and its territory; also a prophet
happy; Asher, a son of Jacob, and the tribe descended from him, with its territory; also a place in Palestine

properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
to go (causatively, bring) out, in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively, direct and proxim.
